Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Damage detection and performance assessment of wind turbine blades
Award.AbstractNarration:
Current global competition for fossil fuels has motivated the prosperity of sustainable energy infrastructures such as wind turbine mills. Wind turbine blades, usually assembled by composite materials, are one of the most vulnerable structures due to their growing self-weight and harsh operational environment. Skyscraping maintenance cost spent on condition assessment through a turbine's service life has caused wind energy to be less cost-effective comparing to conventional resources. Reliable approaches are currently sought to assess turbine blade's structural performance without high expenditure. Considering that most structural failures are initiated from early material deteriorations such as cracks or corrosion, an in situ structural health monitoring system may be employed to alert early signs of material worn-outs, preventing catastrophic structural failures possibly taking place in the future. In collaboration with Dr. Yuan-Sen Yang at the National Taipei University of Technology in Taiwan, this projects aims to employ emerging damage sensing technologies to perform damage assessment of lab-scaled wind turbine blades. Dr. Yang's lab will provide unique dynamic testing facility for lab-scaled turbine blades, and expertise on dynamic characterization of turbine blade performance.

A self-assembled, carbon nanotube-based nanocomposite material is employed as the strain sensor, whose damage sensing capability has been verified on composite material coupons. It will be customized to perform spatial damage detection for lab-scaled wind turbine blades. Structural dynamic responses of the same blades under rotational motion will be taken via the digital image correlation technique - a non-contact motion tracking method - through utilization of a high-speed video camera. A computational model based on both measurements will be established to simulate multidimensional damage aspects of a turbine blade under different operational conditions, thereby providing all-around performance assessment and predictions of the wind turbine's structural conditions. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Science Council of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In summer 2014 I was chosen to be an EAPSI fellow, conducting research in Taiwan on condition assessment of wind turbine blades with Prof. Yuan-Sen Yang from National Taipei University of Science and Technology (NTUST). As one of the most fragile components, the turbine blades usually suffer from a variety kinds of damage due to unpredictable overloads, aerodynamic instability, and harsh operating environment, etc. Real-time monitoring of structural behaviors may prevent disastrous failure at their early stage, but current technology offers limited competence for all-around damage detection. A carbon nanotube based polymeric thin film is proposed to function as a spatial damage detector for turbine blades, with validation tests planned on a lab-scaled turbine blade offered by Prof. Yang. A data acquisition(DAQ) system is designed specifically for sensor installation on turbines; its validity has been verified through preliminary tests during the collaboration period.

The collaboration with Prof. Yang has offered me opportunities to team work with a variety of scholars. I co-worked with a local graduate student on verifying the functionality of a current resource device, getting close communication with other team members on data sharing, material purchasing and result discussion. The openness on communication of my lab mates not only gives me inspirations on different problem-solving approaches, but also makes me feel comfortable working in the lab. Besides training my collaborating students on how to fabricate the thin film materials, I also got the chance to learn how to use a multi-channel DAQ device developed by National Instruments. In addition to getting help from local students on purchasing laboratory materials, I was also able to walk out buying materials on my own from local retailers, getting to know different tools and facilities. I was also invited to a couple of technical tours including visiting a local water reservoir, seeing the beautiful natural landscape of Taiwan. My experience of spending time in a typhoon day is also lifetime unforgettable, reminding me the importance of my research on maintaining reliable structural integrity under harsh environment.

My collaborating experience with Prof. Yang in Taiwan is pivotal to the proceeding of my research back in Davis. Together we have established a data sharing platform on hardware development and analytical result comparison. Our communication upon improvement of DAQ system development, result discussion, and exchange of information since then are prompt and frequent. The training I have received on data collection expanded my knowledge of electronic devices for DAQ, and I have maintained a good connection with my collaborator. The entire collaboration has ensured a steady progress of my research, which certainly will provide a solution for comprehensive damage assessment of turbine blades.
